*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28*.proposition: Permits modification of custody orders upon a showing of material and substantial change in circumstances in the best interests of the child.

*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31*.proposition: Defines joint custody and establishes best interests of the child as the standard for custody decisions.

G.L. c. 209B, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, as well as the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA), G.L. c. 209B, § 2, because this is the Court that entered the original custody order and Massachusetts is the home state of the minor children.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Affirms that the child’s welfare is the paramount concern in custody determinations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames its analysis in terms of the “best interests of the child” and expressly states that the child’s best interests are the paramount concern, even when considering the custodial parent’s interests in a removal case. Although the opinion is about custody and removal (not just initial custody alone), it clearly affirms the overarching principle that in these determinations the child’s welfare is primary and controls the analysis.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’… The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Reiterates that the best interests of the child standard governs modification requests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody matters the "touchstone inquiry" is what is best for the child and then applies that standard to determine primary physical custody of Jill. Although this is not a modification proceeding per se, the court reiterates and relies on the best interests of the child standard as the governing framework for determining custodial arrangements, which is the same standard applied to custody modifications.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’….’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: States that interfering with the child’s relationship with the other parent can justify modifying custody.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on initial custody determination (sole vs. joint custody) and visitation in light of parental antagonism and differing child‑rearing philosophies, not on modifying a prior custody order because one parent interfered with the child’s relationship with the other. There is no discussion of a change of circumstances, interference with the noncustodial parent’s relationship as a basis for modification, or standards for modifying custody on that ground. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the proposition that such interference can justify modifying custody.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “The husband argues that the judge erred in awarding sole custody to the wife and in so doing wrongfully presumed that maternal preference was in the children’s best interests… However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings…”

*Schultz v. Kelly*, 32 Mass. App. Ct. 23.proposition: Recognizes emotional harm to the child as a factor in modifying custody.
*Schultz v. Kelly*, 32 Mass. App. Ct. 23.case_name: Long v. Board of Appeals of Falmouth
*Schultz v. Kelly*, 32 Mass. App. Ct. 23.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a zoning and land-use case concerning special permits and zoning freezes under Massachusetts General Laws c. 40A and c. 41. It does not involve custody, family law, or any discussion of emotional harm to a child, nor any standards for modifying custody. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for recognizing emotional harm to the child as a factor in modifying custody.
*Schultz v. Kelly*, 32 Mass. App. Ct. 23.relevant_excerpt: The appeal raises the issue of the breadth of one’s right to a zoning freeze under G. L. c. 40A, § 6, sixth par., as amended through St. 1986, c. 557, § 54, based upon a planning board’s endorsement of a plan “approval not required” (ANR), pursuant to G. L. c. 41, § 81P, as amended by St. 1987, c. 122. We conclude that the statutory right is broad enough to include Price’s attempt, however calculated, to invoke the freeze.

*D.F. v. J.F.*, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 184 (2.proposition: Addresses unilateral decision-making as a basis for changing legal custody arrangements.

*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.proposition: Affirms that decisions undermining the child’s relationship with the other parent may warrant a custody modification.
*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether to give comity to a Lebanese religious tribunal’s custody decree and whether Massachusetts has jurisdiction, not about modifying an existing Massachusetts custody order based on one parent undermining the child’s relationship with the other. The court’s best‑interests discussion focuses on differences between Massachusetts and Jaafarite law and on duress in the mother’s Lebanese custody agreement, not on parental interference or alienation as grounds for custody modification. Thus it does not establish or affirm the proposition that decisions undermining the child’s relationship with the other parent may warrant a custody modification.
*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of a child is the overarching principle that governs custody disputes in the Commonwealth. … What is in a child’s best interest depends upon the particular needs of the child, and is left largely to the discretion of the judge, who ‘may consider any factor pertinent to those interests.’ … The best interests analysis our courts employ is thus unlike the presumptive entitlement to custody that governed the custody proceeding in the Jaafarite Court in Lebanon.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Emphasizes that stability and minimizing conflict are central to a child’s well-being.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly criticizes the trial judge for prioritizing bonding over the child’s need for stability and quotes prior precedent emphasizing that maintaining an existing parenting arrangement and avoiding unnecessary disruption is ordinarily in the child’s best interests. It also notes that the judge’s actions “significantly disrupted the child’s stability” and endorses legislative policy that gives “primacy to the stability of a nonmarital child.” This directly supports the idea that stability and minimizing disruptive conflict are central to a child’s well-being.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart… and to fashion custody and visitation orders… again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (‘If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child’).”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Confirms that substantial interference with the custodial parent’s rights or time supports a modification request.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the standards for an initial (or reheard) custody determination and reiterates that the child’s welfare and best interests are the governing considerations. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody order, nor does it address substantial interference with the custodial parent’s rights or time as a basis for modification. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific modification-related proposition stated.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”
